messageBody:
On Tuesday 31 May 2005 09:24, Chris Dollin wrote:

> Doesn't follow. You are confusing the "ordering doesn't matter"
> property of various methods on an object - ie, that each ordering
> makes sense from that object's viewpoint, no order is more "right"
> than another - with the "ordering matters" viewpoint of the *user*
> of that object desiring a *specific effect*.

Here's an example. C is a Calculator object. It's a very primitive
calculator: it has load(N), add(), mul(), and answer() operations
only, and N is integers mod whatever, so there's no pesky overflow
exceptions to get in the way.

Calculator { int A; int B;
void load(int N) { B = A; A = N; }
void add() { A = A + B; }
void mul() { A = A * B; }
int answer() { return A; } }

Now, *any* sequence of method calls on C is well-defined, eg

Calculator C = new Calculator();
assertEquals( 0, C.answer() );
C.load(17); assertEquals( 17, C.answer() );
C.load(2); C.load(3); C.add(); assertEquals( 5, C.answer() );
C.load(2); C.load(3); C.mul(); assertEquals( 6, C.answer() );
C.load(2); C.load(3); C.add(); C.mul(); assertEquals( 10, C.answer() );

Equally clearly, if you want to add 1, 2, and 3 together to get the
usual answer, the sequence

load(1); load(2); load(3); add(); add();

while *legal* and *meaningful* isn't *right*, but

load(1); load(2); add(); load(3); add();

is. (The results of both are independant of previous Calculator
state.)

[Credit will be given to those who identify the source of the AB
register structure.]
